Everyone here acting like a saint and saying they should be treated fairly with equal amount of food. How about everyone that say so, give them what you have? Come on, we are humans after all. We are selfish to an extent. From what I see, those food despite being not ok, I personally think that it’s at least they have food. They chose to come Singapore to work yo. It takes two hands to clap. We didn’t force them here. So stop saying “oh you are living in the Hdb that they built”. In addition, in time of crisis, we should always priorities our citizen first. After all, would you allow your own children to suffer? If you had to choose between your own child and outsider child, would you be able to treat both of them equally?
@joteo.ylm

Though I agree that the quality of the food given to foreign workers needs to improve, I don't see any point in attacking the gov over this. The food provided to these workers are free of charge. We must also look at the number of sgreans serving SHN vs the number of foreign workers in the dorms. I'm no expert on the numbers, but I can assure you that there are many more foreign workers. Furthermore, these foreign workers, while they do contribute massively to our development and economy, are not Singaporeans loyal to the state. It may sound petty, but I don't think any country in the world would treat others better than their own people. I've seen many sgreans complain a lot during these trying times and I might dare say that if the food of the foreign workers was better than that of the SGreans serving SHN, people would be complaining "why foreign workers get better food than sg people?" Lastly, it could very well be the employers of these foreign workers providing the food for the workers. Not everything has to do with the gov, who alr have their hands full with controlling the covid-19 situation, dealing with some irresponsible people who refuse to adhere to the guidelines and keeping the general public calm. It's not easy and I feel we should be more appreciative than nitpick on every small thing that they do. In the end, we should definitely be wanting better for everyone, but there is nothing gained in pointing fingers, but instead, we should stay strong, cooperative and united at this time.
@just_british

text: @papsingapore
Its hilarious how we need a pandemic to tell us the treatment of foreign construction workers is terrible

if you’re accepting of how Singapore treats our foreign workers, you are part of the problem and the reason why bigger change cannot be made. Foreign Workers are still human beings, to work in a country not of their own to be build all of your MRT,HDB basically every infrastructure that makes Singapore WHAT & in fact, all that it is. 
You’re bullshitting your only excuse is that Singapore is too small or that they are already getting more than they deserve.

Everything around us is built by who? You guessed it, foreign workers & many more people. 
Literally you’re living in a home built by hard work of many men who tire themselves every single day. To provide a humane accommodation is not asking for gold. They may not be Singaporeans but their labour work deserves more than what it gets credit for.  You may be under the impression that they are asking for it but seriously? These people HAVE NEVER COMPLAINED. THEY DEAL WITH THIS CRAP. 
THEY TAKE IT ALL IN and continue living despite the challenges because that’s how you survive. And you compare that to people, our Singaporean’s complaining about minor inconvenience? Y’all don’t understand how bloody annoying it is. 
Some of you don’t understand how difficult this is. You really don’t. In technchnicality there’s a lot of unjust and imbalance and YES we do more for our foreign workers than other countries treat their own but you have to realise. It’s difficult to convert empathy to actual change but please widen your perspective. 
Things are always difficult to change but please don’t even TRY to say that’s what they are deserving of. Bringing light to this problem is one thing, but literally nothing is being done. 
So now my question is, how bad does the situation have to get for the people in power to realise there’s a problem?

answers.text: @_turbocharged your racist ass don’t deserve to be in Singapore.

@diamdante it may be marginal in other times, but now in this covid 19 situation, supply is already being cut off due to the circuit breaker measures. Any further increase in costs will significantly increase prices. Charity is alright, it's your own money after all, you have the right to give it to whom you see fit. If you want to donate to foreign workers you do you, but I'll prefer to help my fellow Singaporeans first.

@ryan.is.kohld ohh the irony. Seems like you yourself have no clue. No matter how discontent they were, violent demonstrations is against Singapore law. If they don't respect that, then it just proves my point. They will never be satisfied and will keep demanding more, and if we give them what they want, it will only embolden them to use more drastic measures

@_turbocharged this shows you have absolutely 0 awareness of social affairs. The little india riots was caused by a build-up of anger in the foreign worker community over our treatment of them by their employers. They toil for our housing, for our public amenities, for the singapore we want. We should at least show them some form of respect and treat them as humans, rather than slaves. They will take a mile, but they will give back 278.6 square miles, because they are the ones who have built and is still building our country

@diamdante anyway I'm not sure if this is relevant or helps my argument in any way, but I myself am a Singaporean with a comfortable life (my family is not rich but we can def afford some frivolous things) and from your other replies you seem like you're in same kind of situation too. A few dollars that we donate to those charities that help migrant workers (or local Singaporeans if that's what you choose) will not gonna hurt us in any way, will directly help a few people in need and will (kind of) sidestep a lot of the larger "economic" problems you mentioned above by not taking food out of other people's mouths!!! Why not go for that instead :)

@_turbocharged thats a good statement: I think we have finally reached the core of our argument. Everything that you said in the last comment is true EXCEPT that "the costs outweighs the benefits". The monetary costs associated with feeding foreign workers slightly better food for only 14 days is marginal — the miniscule impact it would have on our reserves / housing prices would likely never even be passed on to us "regular" Singaporeans

@diamdante depends on which unit you're from tho. Some have it better than the others but the general consensus is that more can be done to improve the nutrition of NS food in general, at least that's what my friends who ORDed last year said. There will be some freak cases but in general I still feel that most firms would do their best to comply with MOM standards. The food looks unappetising sure, but that doesn't mean it's inedible or not nutritious. Also, the quote may be biased as well, as they may say such things to influence opinion and put pressure on the employers to provide more expensive food. If the money for more expensive food comes from the government, then that means less reserves for us in general. If it's from the employers' own pockets, then it will raise the prices of housing as I've mentioned in previous replies above. So either way, the costs outweigh any benefit that might arise from this.

@diamdante sorry to spam again :( but I think fundamentally one of the things I'm arguing against is that every extra bit of normal vegetable we give to a foreign worker in quarantine is NOT a bowl of rice being taken away from another Singaporean. This is just a call for more care to be taken when providing food during this 14 days of mandatory quarantine in the dormitories that was announced yesterday(the day before?). Not such a big widescale reallocation of precious resources as you are implying

@_turbocharged sorry it's a bit mean to generalize about you or your age, but before I ORD-ed (two years ago) the food was not exactly shit quality.... it was not good, but still ok.  And the sentence "it's against SG law.... no one would do that" is actually not true at all. Many firms have been charged over the past few years with various offences related to fw treatment. And even if there was some exaggeration involved, I don't think it can be that much considering the post also includes a quote from an actual recipient and a photo of the food, which doesn't exactly give the activist much room to highly exaggerate
@april__m_t I'm actually a millennial but thanks for generalising. Also, using boomer as an insult in 2020 is pretty pathetic and uncreative on your part 😂

@diamdante "extreme" is relative. I'm pretty sure channeling resources to improve quality of NS food first and foremost is a more efficient use of our resources. And btw, I'm pretty sure this is hyperbole and exaggerated. Feeding people rotten food is against Singapore law and no firms with common sense would do that. A more likely scenario is that the food is just bland and not very visually appealing, and some of those bleeding hearts foreign worker rights champions wrote a highly exaggerated paragraph to deliberately draw sympathy from people like you.

@cowmoomoocow great misinterpretation of my comment. I have actually mentioned in my previous comment that I don't feel they should be treated like shit, but their current conditions are satisfactory. It will disrupt as it will upset the distinction between citizens (who have full privileges) and foreigners (who have no affiliation to the nation and thus are not entitled to the full privileges here). Upsetting the balance and distinction may result in them increasing their demands, as the saying goes,"give them an inch, they'll take a mile). And btw, I did actually make money on my own, and I am semi successful now and have a satisfactory life, though I came from a poor family. Yes, welfare handouts draw on our reserves and potentially cause a govt budget deficit, but at least it is more justified to spend on locals first instead of foreigners.
@_turbocharged definitely a boomer

@_turbocharged hey man not to continue to drag the argument out any longer, but I think the root of the problem is that your thinking and choice of words are a bit extreme. To say that "FW are all we care about" is pretty inaccurate — this is just one of the ways which we can be better during this coronavirus period. To say we want the government to "babysit" them to live a life of "affluence" is also inaccurate and missing the point of this post — we just want that for the limited period of this coronavirus quarantine their food is just regular, standard, not-rotten meat, vegetables and rice. That's a much more reasonable demand imo than what you interpreted from the post :')

@_turbocharged what on earth is wrong w u. I believe everyone shld be treated fairly just bcus they're foreign workers doesnt mean they can be treated like shit. If an expat were to be quarantined do u think they will be treated the same way? How will providing them with some temporary help actually disrupt our society. And just so uk im pretty sure the govt has done a lot to help our many low income families and people in need. If u think the govt shldnt be helping them bcus it 'disrupting society' then shldnt all those relief funds that r given out my the govt redundant and disrupting economy as well? Doesn't mean u come from a family that's not well to do then u have to dump all the hate on those innocent workers. Maybe u need to reflect on why u couldnt make more money on ur own without the help of the govt?

@slws__ gratitude is one thing. I've never denied they should be praised for their labour. However there should be a clear distinction between verbal appreciation and actions that will disrupt society, such as channeling our resources to improve their living standards when government is facing a deficit already due to covid 19 situation. Also, like I have already explained. Drastically improving benefits for them is not economically viable due to the increase in production costs which will spill into property prices and cause an increase there as well.
@_lunadefresa_ I've already explained my stance. Hardly ignorance I'm displaying. If you have no other useful input to add then farewell.
@chocolatepiezzz glad to see someone who agrees

@_turbocharged Does it hurt for you to show some compassion to foreign workers? Yes, they left their country to seek a better life in Singapore. But we should also be thankful for everything they have done. Do you think there are many Singaporeans who would like working in a construction site environment?

@_turbocharged Unpopular opinion but yes I agree with u... Know of someone who doesn't even have enough money to buy meat and veges everyday, just eats rice w soya sauce. In any country, the citizens should come first, they are the ones who pay the taxes and contribute to what the rest of us gets too, and yes, before I get attacked, we should definitely help the foreigners too but AFTER the citizens are taken care of first
@_turbocharged sigh if this mentality helps you sleep at night, then so be it. Ignorance is bliss for some i suppose 🤷🏻‍♀️

@_lunadefresa_ the fact that we have homelessness in sg is bad enough. Gov should channel their resources to combat this first and foremost. Also, MOM can't do anything about this, as efforts to improve living conditions will only drive up inflation and drive up property prices, which will cause discontentment among Singaporeans. Analysing cost and benefit, maintaing the status quo is still the most desirable option

@_turbocharged again, people can care about and work on multiple things. Right now singapore is at a 3.62% unemployment rate majority of that percentage being citizens who are physically unable to work, with only an average of 1000 homeless in comparison to our population of almost 6mil. Is it still a problem? Of course. But it is still manageable and under control. Im not saying the govt shouldnt care about the citizens or domestic issues, but it does not cancel out the issues foreign workers face. We are calling for MOM specifically to assert their power in this situation and not shy away from it just because the employers of these foreign workers care more about lining their pockets than they do about the welfare of their staff. It is not a case of “one is more important than the other” but it is a case of “something can be done but nothing is being done”

@_lunadefresa_ it does not invalidate yes, but our priority is to ensure domestic poverty is alleviated first before we start to care about foreigners. Oh, and the spoilt veg and living in crowded spaces thing, umm you do realise NS exists right? Not that I'm complaining about it, but we clearly know how it's like, but I'm saying that we have more pressing issues domestically.

@_turbocharged you do realize people can care about more than one thing right? Yes, there are singaporeans who have no food or are struggling financially. That does not invalidate or downplay the struggles foreign workers go through. I’d like to see if you went to a different country and they served you spoilt vegetables and made you live in one room with 20 other people would you actually be happy and not complain.

@_turbocharged self-reflection appears to be difficult for you, so let me help you break it down: 1. you believe travelling to singapore to work for a shitty pay, to build a city for people like you who can't appreciate their efforts, and forced to stay on lockdown because they aren't provided adequate housing and now may suffer from a deadly coronavirus, are privileged to be here. if anything, if you can speak like that, you're the one in a privileged position. worse still, since you claim to have suffered from a similar if not worse experience, the fact that you can't empathise with their position says a lot more about your character. your attitude and character has degenerated to a point you can't even empathise with others' suffering. 2. tiktok is irrelevant. every child has their cringy moments. there are talented people on tiktok who can dance, sing, act, and entertain immensely well - and they are a thousand times more compassionate than you, who can't even spare a thought for a worker that doesn't get food that can't even be considered a meal. i don't think anything i say will change your attitude - firstly because i'm just an internet stranger, and secondly because you're too self-absorbed in your superiority complex, riding the wave of "i worked so hard to get where i am! i'm better than everyone else!", so i'll end my piece here. i'm sorry for you and hope you'll grow to be a better person with whatever time you have left (idk ur age).

text: It's not the government that does this you know right? It's the organisations that employ these workers. THEY ARE the ones that stinge on food and other essentials to cut costs. I understand raising awareness. But please don't mindlessly vent anger on the average Joe because he is unaware of what's happening. The employers are the one that see this conditions on a daily, and are CONTENT with it as long as their pockets are thick. How do THEY LIVE with themselves at all? I am only aware of these type of conditions because I used to work with our foreign workers and they would share with me these atrocities. However despite being a Singaporean, I couldn't do much. These organisations go beyond what we can control. It's not something we can fix with a switch. And telling the necessary channels didn't get me anywhere either. Believe me, the blaming game means nothing in the wide scale of things. Why shame People that receive good food, instead of just being angry about how our foreign works are being treated poorly? We should work to improve lives, but not shame others especially when they aren't in a loop of the situation

No hate, just my opinion.

@liseran_ about being treated like human beings. The company I worked at. Didn't even give chairs to these workers during a meeting. They made them gather and sit on the floor in the middle of the office, reprimanding them aggressively like it was morning assembly in primary school. And I couldn't do anything at that moment without risking my own job stability there. These companies really need to be weeded out and investigated on a daily to ensure that real change can happen
@pigmichgeon Yes, and the employers will continue doing nothing about it until the GOVERNMENT instores LEGISLATION to PROHIBIT such treatment.. such a long paragraph for so little content..

@liseran_ exactly! These foreign workers were my colleagues, and yet they were so grossly treated and underpaid, despite work at least 20 hours OT a week. And their catered food would spoil within 2 hours. But the management did nothing to change any of this. I couldn't do anything but treat my colleagues to lunches whenever I can to make up where I can.
@pigmichgeon yes exactly! thats why i said that the government should step in and have checks and standards for the standard of accommodations.
@pigmichgeon facts. Totally agree with what you've said. It's the middle management that has to change and treat these workers like human beings.

text: And can I just mention the ridiculous amount of plastic containers on the singaporeans' lunch tray OMG😱...can just use plates and bowls what💁‍♂️

answers.text: @cantthinkofanothernameso aren’t the people posting their meals actually under quarantine? Isn’t it safer to use single use items rather than risking infection?

@kevindoublechin @ebi.exe its a hotel, they do large events. They have to be prepared for hundreds of guests. I’m sure they’ll have utensils. It’s actually a greater waste of resources if you use single-use plastic since there’s the costs of buying these plastics then the cost to the environment I.e. transportation costs (fuel, pollution etc.), amount of water used to manufacture the plastic (greater than washing), amount of energy needed to produce the plastics, then after it gets thrown away (since you need to wash to recycle)- landfill space used up + plastic & eventual microplastic pollution.
@kevindoublechin you got a good point there🙁😅
@kevindoublechin  t🙁
@kevindoublechin ikr, if u dont choose to use plastic bowls, etc, you gonna pay ppl to wash the plates & pay for the water, electricity for dryer and probably more

answers.text: @eren.hun @ashmenao @_nancyboii_ @icedmilonoice

@dempots_demcans 1. Singapore is a democratic government. Government decided upon voting by its citizens. Naturally, it has to focus its attention towards its citizens with better welfare in order to garner more votes. Thats also one of the negative effects of democracy. 2. Citizens makes up the majority of all nations in the world. With only that much resources, and only 1 government, its not possible to please everyone since everyone has different needs and wants. Therefore, only majority can possibly be satisfied. So welfare is focused on its citizens. If all is divided equally regardless of your title of citizen or not, the concept of true equality among all in itself is going towards communism and no longer democracy. (Theres also an issue of difference in tax payment and economic contribution but im not exactly certain hence ill just leave u with the benefit of the doubt).

@dempots_demcans the whole time "preferential treatment" i mentioned, i was referring to social welfare and benefits (basic examples include medisave medishield etc) such as these. Yes of course, not everyone is de facto equal, even on grounds of citizenship, but the law should treat then t

@dempots_demcans would also like to point out that all you managed to do in your point here is that 1. You described the situation which they are facing, which is literally the whole focus of this IG post, and 2. You brought up the topic of subpar wages. Which, i also covered previously on the topic of that (which i explained is off topic and irrelevant and unjustified due to the fact that, allow me to repeat myself, labor costs in sg is already higher than most countries in the world.)
@realityczecher well then you did not justify your point stating that they should not get the same quality of food as a native citizen. Go on. Justify it.

@dempots_demcans the whole point of what iv been saying is not about something vague and in the ether like the concept of "loyalty to state". Instead its that preferential treatment by the government has to go towards the citizens simply due to the fact that they are citizens. After all thats the whole point of such a title, label. The government revolves around its citizens and not its inhabitants. Tax money and government welfare has to be focused around somewhere and not just thrown towards whatever inhabitants it contains. A country where theres no difference in treatment between inhabitants and citizens doesnt exist and for a reason.

@dempots_demcans yeah so all you basically repeated whatever points i covered and less: their labor wages are underwhelming, they deserve better food than that at least for a human being, also, i DIDNT mention at all that loyalty is a factor of consideration towards welfare of treatment.

@realityczecher Do you know how much they are paid? Wanna take a gamble? 15$ a day. No, not an hour. A day. Of course if I asked you if you wanted free food, and all you got was a disgusting ration, you'd buy your own food instead. But earning 15$ a day, I think you would take the disgusting food that no one with a choice would eat. And again, loyalty to the state has nothing to do with quality of food. Not all Singaporeans are loyal to the state. And not all foreign workers are entirely disloyal to it. When two people are in the same situation of requring food, that is the only condition they should fulfil: being human. You shouldn't give more or less or better or worse food to one or the other for any reason. Loyalty to the state just doesn't fit in at all into the quality of food. Your argument does not make sense.

@dempots_demcans well yeah. We do infact have to give them what they deserve. They built the country. Correct. The food is trash unfitting of a human, right. They deserve better, of course. But do they deserve the same as the usual citizens? Not necessarily. Moral issue? Unfounded as we should definitely give them what they deserve, which is better ofc. They are paid laborer. You can proceed to argue about them not being paid enough for sure. But even then, singapore already has one of the higher labor costs in the world compared to others. They arent slaves definitely therefore your reasoning based on the concept of "morality" to justify giving them the exact same treatment as citizens is unjustified and instead is an act of moral kidnapping.

@muhdmuntazhar order refers to societal order, and the order of law and citizenship rights in sg. By distinction, I'm pertaining to the fact that workers need to realise they're not citizens, they can't demand to be treated the same way. Such order and distinction between the two groups is essential to ensure they do not step out of line and cause disruption to society (remember the little India riots?).
@dempots_demcans Good try. But i do not argue with those who are ignorant.

@dan.ialll I understand where you are coming from. Such righteousness is normal. What do you think will happen if foreigners and PRs receive the same treatment in every aspect of life? @steroidandroid What the fuck?? Because they're not Singaporean, they shouldn't get food worthy of human rights? There is no possible justification for treating the people that built Singapore in this manner.
@chaiperfection yes thank you for understanding.
@steroidandroid I'm not saying that they have to get quality similar to that of those under SHN, but at least proper decent balanced meals. Which I'm pretty sure that's also what you're saying.

@steroidandroid I understand what you mean when you say that the food they receive doesn't have to be on par as people serving SHN. And I am aware that they are completely different circumstances. However, I have heard of cases where the workers just get rice and plain curry drizzled over it. No veggie, no meat. Furthermore, to simply have a diet that mostly compromises of carbohydrates is not sustainable for anyone regards of their jobscope. Meals should be more balance because humans need a certain amount of nutrients not found in rice, but veggies and meat in order for us to be healthy. Just take a look at the food pyramid. In the long term, if humans lack certain nutrients, it can cause irreversible health problems, like the lack of iron can cause anemia, or if carbohydrate intake is too high, it can lead to diabetes. I also know that a lot of people are not aware that the food are delivered so early that the food go bad, that's why I'm trying to bring more awareness to this issue.
@dan.ialll I am not saying they should not receive proper food, i am just saying that they should not receive the same quality of food (hotel standard).

@chaiperfection Firstly, please understand that these workers are not working, they are under quarantine. Secondly, i am not aware of how the food is delivered, so in any case, if possible, the delivery timing can be better planned. Lastly, just because your diet isnt as such, doesnt mean they are not treated as humans. Their diet comprises of mainly carbohydrates(eg rice), due to the nature of their jobs. So they are used to this kind of food. But of course, they should receive more meat and vegetables if possible.

@1_m_r4m._ While i do agree that they deserve better treatment, it doesnt mean they should receive exactly the same treatment. It may not be right, but also note that there is a huge difference between the school fees of Singaporeans and PRs. If even PRs are not receiving the same treatment as Singaporeans, why should foreigners? There must be a distinction between the treatment of citizens and others(PRs and foreigners), because the welfare of the citizens of a country should be the priority. But again, i must stress that the foreign workers deserve better food and living conditions.
@steroidandroid how to call it food if not edible?

But that does not mean they should receive poor quality food, and in fact i did state repeatedly that the quality of their food should be improved.

@fknimamalol but not everything should be attributed to the “government” though. Not like if my zichar stall food tastes like shit I blame the govt. The dorm operators, not the “govt.” should be taken to task in cases like that.
@rachel.dajx sure whatever...
@daniel_ho_jt i said eq for a reason
@rachel.dajx its iq
@kungfuvenny plus im very sure this situation that is happening to the workers, is the small minority. mom has regulations to keep the well being of workers in check.
@daniel_ho_jt clearly this dude has zero eq, how dare you say that

@kungfuvenny I think it's just that a lot of people are very used to that mentality, tbh it's a mentality that most Singaporeans are guilty of and something that I've also found frustrating. Change is hard. But hopefully with more awareness, people will be open to change and do something about it :)

@chaiperfection OP saying that they are “powerless” and “cannot do anything except convince the government to treat them better” and then following it up with “idet the govt will listen to us” kinda just shows the mentality OP has, the mentality that you can’t really do anything or create change, hence why I said I said. However I do agree that not enough attention is brought to this situation and not many are educated about ways to help & etc. But yes, let’s all do our best to help one another in this tough time be it big or small. Small actions are still actions! :)

@kungfuvenny I don't think they're shrugging it off? Yes, I do agree this mentality makes it worse but I feel like there's just not enough awareness because even myself, I never knew how I could help before I found the small organisations/individuals that do their best to help these people. Let's all be supportive and encouraging:)
@daniel_ho_jt i am just shit-posting ^just read
@daniel_ho_jt that is something a daniel would say honestly. ain’t surprised 🤷‍♀️
@daniel_ho_jt what the hell man

@fknimamalol You can’t just have this mindset. Everyone is capable of change no matter how small. Donations, speaking up, spreading awareness for change is still help. Having this mentality (and spreading it on social media) in this time just makes everything worse. Foreign workers work so hard for us, the least you can do is to at least try rather than shrug it off.
@sumtin_tai  PAP FOR LIFE
@daniel_ho_jt ???
@daniel_ho_jt uhmmm.....

@deloreanflight oi dont anyhow say the pap bad. Without them Singapore would be a shit hole. So let them do what ever they want. The want to sign thousands upon thousands of foreign workers from india, i say let them. Let the foreigners be cramped into a small living space, bad food management, broken toilets etc. They are the PAP they do what is right

@no_name_42069 @fknimamalol you guys can search for itsrainingraincoats on FB. This lady organises food distributions to foreign workers and sometimes she needs help be it financial or physical help to hand out the food
@fknimamalol local mp go complain

@yea_internet_tbh i'm too lazy to discuss here but definitely the government should have some sort of standards and checks for these companies that manage the hostels. they're the problem thats causing the foreign workers to live like this. government has to step in and not allow this corruption to continue.
@deloreanflight well what system would you suggest?
@yea_internet_tbh like for how long you or me or we alone are gonna them food everyday? nothing will improve. there needs to be a system in place.

@fknimamalol you can do something to help like giving them food?
@fknimamalol maybe, i hope that the govt will actually do something about this. maybe a petition regarding this would help, idk
